beta-carotene from mixed carotenoids.notes: Variable based on fat intake; requires conversion to active Vitamin A.

retinyl palmitate.notes: Preformed vitamin A with 70-90% absorption. Synthetic but highly effective.

retinyl acetate.notes: Preformed vitamin A, well absorbed. Stable in formulations.

beta-carotene synthetic.notes: Poor conversion to vitamin A; lower bioavailability compared to natural sources.

dunaliella salina (natural).notes: Algae source of mixed carotenoids, including beta-carotene. Better than synthetic forms.

retinol (free form).notes: Highly bioavailable, but unstable in supplements; rarely found in this free form.

vitamin A from cod liver oil.notes: Natural source, includes Vitamin D and Omega-3s. Excellent bioavailability.
aliases: cod liver oil vitamin a supplement
vitamin a from fish liver supplement
fish liver oil vitamin a supplement

vitamin A palmitate in oil.notes: Oil-based delivery improves absorption for this fat-soluble form. Common and stable.

micellized vitamin A.notes: Water-soluble micelle form for enhanced absorption, particularly useful for individuals with fat malabsorption.

liposomal vitamin A.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for superior delivery and bioavailability, bypassing some digestive hurdles.

thiamine disulfide.notes: Less bioavailable than mononitrate and hydrochloride; used in some older formulations.

benfotiamine.notes: Fat-soluble synthetic form, highly bioavailable and able to cross cell membranes effectively. Beneficial for nerve health.

thiamine mononitrate.notes: Standard synthetic form, stable in supplements and common in fortified foods.

thiamine hydrochloride.notes: Water-soluble synthetic form, widely used and well-established.

allithiamine.notes: Garlic-derived, lipid-soluble form, crosses cell membranes easily for improved tissue delivery.

sulbutiamine.notes: Synthetic derivative, specifically designed to cross the blood-brain barrier for cognitive support.

thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP).notes: Active coenzyme form, readily used by the body in metabolic pathways.

thiamine diphosphate (TDP).notes: Metabolically active form, crucial for enzyme function and energy production.

thiamine tetrahydrofurfuryl disulfide (T.notes: Highly bioavailable synthetic form, used for rapid thiamine repletion and neurological support.

thiamine from brewer's yeast.notes: Natural food-based source, includes cofactors for better utilization.

thiamine oxide.notes: Oxidized form, significantly lower bioavailability and effectiveness.

thiamine analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

thiamine degraded by thiaminase.notes: Destroyed by enzymes found in raw fish, some plants, and tea/coffee, which can lead to deficiency.

riboflavin-5-phosphate.notes: Active coenzyme form (FMN), bypasses initial conversion step for immediate utilization.

riboflavin.notes: Standard synthetic form, requires conversion to active FMN/FAD in the body.

riboflavin from yeast.notes: Food-based source, includes cofactors and other B vitamins for synergistic effects.

flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).notes: Active coenzyme form, directly involved in numerous metabolic reactions.

riboflavin analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

riboflavin degraded by light.notes: Photodegraded form, loses potency significantly when exposed to light.

nicotinamide riboside.notes: Advanced NAD+ precursor, highly bioavailable and avoids the 'niacin flush.'

nicotinamide mononucleotide.notes: Direct NAD+ precursor, popular in longevity research. Highly absorbable.

inositol hexanicotinate.notes: No-flush form of niacin, slowly released and gentle on the system. Supports lipid metabolism.

niacinamide.notes: Non-flushing form, preferred for skin health and cellular repair without vasodilation.

nicotinic acid.notes: Traditional form, can cause the 'niacin flush' (vasodilation) at higher doses.

niacinamide ascorbate.notes: Combined with vitamin C, aims to reduce flushing, but efficacy for that is variable.

niacin from tryptophan.notes: Endogenous synthesis from the amino acid tryptophan; requires cofactors like B6 and iron.

niacin analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

niacin degraded by heat.notes: Heat-sensitive form, loses potency during prolonged high-temperature processing.

calcium pantothenate.notes: Stable synthetic form, widely used in supplements and fortified foods.

pantethine.notes: Active form, superior to pantothenic acid for supporting lipid metabolism and Coenzyme A formation.

pantothenic acid.notes: Basic form, requires conversion to Coenzyme A (CoA) in the body.

sodium pantothenate.notes: Less stable than calcium salt, used in some formulations but may degrade faster.

panthenol (pro-vitamin B5).notes: Pro-vitamin form, primarily used topically in cosmetics; not ideal for oral supplementation due to low conversion.

pantothenic acid analogs (inactive).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

pyridoxal-5-phosphate (P5P).notes: Active coenzyme form, directly utilized by the body without conversion. Preferred form for optimal bioavailability.

pyridoxamine.notes: Alternative form found in foods, requires conversion to P5P. Can support enzymatic reactions.

pyridoxine hydrochloride.notes: Most common synthetic form, requires conversion to active P5P, which can be inefficient in some individuals.

pyridoxine glutamate.notes: Rare form, less effective than P5P. May have specific applications but generally less preferred for broad supplementation.

pyridoxine oxide.notes: Oxidized form, very low bioavailability and effectiveness.

pyridoxine analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (P-5-P).notes: Active coenzyme form, bypasses conversion step. Superior for those with genetic polymorphisms.

d-biotin.notes: Natural form, optimal bioavailability. Essential for metabolism of fats, carbs, and proteins.

biotin.notes: Standard synthetic form, widely used. Effective for general supplementation.

biotin from yeast.notes: Food-based source, includes cofactors and other nutrients for enhanced synergy.

biotinidase-released biotin.notes: Biotin released from protein-bound forms via enzymatic digestion, ensuring absorbable free biotin.

biotin analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

biotin degraded by avidin.notes: Irreversibly bound by avidin (a protein in raw egg whites), preventing absorption. Cooking eggs denatures avidin.

5-methyltetrahydrofolate (5-MTHF).notes: Active form, bypasses the MTHFR enzyme conversion, making it highly effective for all individuals.

calcium folinate.notes: Folinic acid, an active form that readily converts to 5-MTHF. Useful for methylation support.

quatrefolic.notes: Patented 5-MTHF glucosamine salt, known for superior stability and bioavailability.

metafolin.notes: Patented calcium 5-MTHF, highly bioavailable and stable form of active folate.

folic acid.notes: Synthetic, inactive form. Up to 40% of people have reduced ability to convert it to active folate (MTHFR polymorphism).

food folate (polyglutamate).notes: Naturally occurring in vegetables, legumes, and liver. Requires enzymatic deconjugation for absorption.

folate from yeast.notes: Food-based source, includes cofactors and other B vitamins, providing a more holistic nutrient profile.
aliases: whole food folate from yeast supplement

folate analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

folate degraded by heat.notes: Heat-sensitive form, susceptible to degradation during cooking and food processing, leading to potency loss.

methylcobalamin.notes: Active coenzyme form, readily utilized for neurological health, methylation, and energy production. Well retained in tissues.

adenosylcobalamin.notes: Supports mitochondrial energy production; synthetically produced for supplements

hydroxocobalamin.notes: Detox-supporting B12; used in injections and cyanide poisoning; synthetically produced

cyanocobalamin.notes: Synthetic form; requires conversion to active forms; lower biological activity

liposomal methylcobalamin.notes: Encapsulated for enhanced delivery and cellular uptake, particularly beneficial for those with absorption issues.

micellized methylcobalamin.notes: Water-soluble micelle form for improved absorption, especially in individuals with fat malabsorption.

b12 from yeast.notes: Food-based source, includes cofactors and other B vitamins for a more complete nutritional profile.

b12 analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit and may interfere with true B12 absorption.

b12 degraded by nitrous oxide.notes: Inactivated by nitrous oxide exposure, which impairs its methylation capabilities. Can lead to functional deficiency.

liposomal vitamin C.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for superior cellular delivery

ester-C (calcium ascorbate).notes: Patented form with calcium threonate and metabolites

sodium ascorbate.notes: Buffered form, commonly used in IV and oral supplements

magnesium ascorbate.notes: Buffered form with added magnesium benefit

ascorbyl palmitate.notes: Fat-soluble form, used in skin and cosmetic products

ascorbyl glucoside.notes: Used in topical formulations, limited oral bioavailability

vitamin C with bioflavonoids.notes: Enhanced by natural flavonoids like hesperidin and rutin

camu camu extract.notes: Amazonian fruit, rich in natural vitamin C and cofactors

acerola cherry extract.notes: Natural source with bioflavonoids and synergistic compounds

potassium ascorbate.notes: Buffered form with potassium, less common

zinc ascorbate.notes: Combined with zinc for immune support

slow-release vitamin C.notes: Timed-release form, absorption may be lower

oxidized vitamin C (dehydroascorbic acid.notes: Oxidized form, less stable and less effective

cholecalciferol (D3).notes: Preferred form, identical to the vitamin D produced by skin exposure to sunlight. Highly bioavailable and well retained.

calcidiol (25-hydroxy D3).notes: Pre-activated form, bypasses the initial liver conversion step, leading to faster and more consistent increases in serum D levels.

micellized D3.notes: Water-soluble micelle form, significantly enhances absorption, especially beneficial for individuals with fat malabsorption issues.

liposomal D3.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for enhanced cellular uptake and bioavailability, protecting the vitamin from degradation.

microencapsulated D3.notes: Protected form, improves stability and absorption by shielding the vitamin from harsh digestive conditions.

vitamin D3 from lichen.notes: Vegan source of D3, bioequivalent to animal-derived cholecalciferol, making it suitable for plant-based diets.

ergocalciferol (D2).notes: Plant-based form, less effective at raising and maintaining serum D levels compared to D3, and has a shorter half-life.

vitamin D2 (unspecified source).notes: Variable potency, often from irradiated yeast or mushrooms. Less reliable than specified sources.

vitamin D2 from UV-treated mushrooms.notes: Natural source, approved for fortification in EU. A vegan option for D2, but still less potent than D3.

vitamin D analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit and can potentially interfere with active vitamin D.

oxidized vitamin D.notes: Degraded by light, heat, or oxidation; loses effectiveness and provides no beneficial activity.

mixed tocopherols.notes: Full spectrum natural form including alpha, beta, gamma, and delta tocopherols. Offers broader antioxidant benefits than alpha-tocopherol alone.
aliases: alpha beta gamma delta tocopherols supplement

d-alpha-tocopherol.notes: Natural RRR form, preferentially retained and utilized by the body, offering superior biological activity to synthetic forms.

tocotrienols.notes: A distinct class of Vitamin E compounds found in palm and rice bran, with superior antioxidant properties, especially delta and gamma forms.
aliases: alpha beta gamma delta tocotrienols supplement

d-alpha-tocopheryl acetate.notes: Stable ester form, widely used in supplements and fortified foods due to its resistance to oxidation.

d-alpha-tocopheryl succinate.notes: Water-dispersible ester, often used in clinical applications and for individuals with fat absorption issues.

dl-alpha-tocopherol.notes: Synthetic all-racemic form, only about half as biologically effective as natural d-alpha-tocopherol.

dl-alpha-tocopheryl succinate.notes: Synthetic ester, less effective than the natural succinate form.

dl-alpha-tocopheryl acetate.notes: Synthetic ester, commonly used in fortified foods and supplements for its stability.

vitamin E from wheat germ oil.notes: Natural food source, rich in d-alpha-tocopherol and other beneficial cofactors, providing a more complete Vitamin E profile.
aliases: natural e from wheat germ supplement

vitamin E analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit and may compete with active Vitamin E.

oxidized vitamin E.notes: Degraded by light or heat, loses its antioxidant function and becomes ineffective.

menaquinone-7 (MK-7).notes: Long-chain form of K2, known for its long half-life and superior bioavailability, particularly beneficial for bone and cardiovascular health.

menaquinone-7 all-trans.notes: Only the active trans-isomer, offering optimal biological activity and superior to mixed cis/trans forms.

menaquinone-4 (MK-4).notes: Shorter chain form of K2, readily utilized but has a shorter half-life requiring more frequent dosing.

vitamin K2 (trans form).notes: Refers to the biologically active configuration of K2 forms, crucial for proper function.

vitamin K2 (cis form).notes: Inactive configuration, has minimal physiological effect and should be avoided.

phylloquinone (K1).notes: Plant-based form found in leafy greens; primarily supports blood clotting and has limited conversion to K2.

vitamin K1 synthetic.notes: Synthetic form, often used in fortified foods and injections for blood clotting support.

vitamin K2 from natto.notes: Fermented soy source, naturally rich in highly bioavailable MK-7. A traditional food source.

vitamin K2 from cheese.notes: Fermented dairy source, contains various menaquinone forms (MK-8 to MK-10).
aliases: vitamin K2 from fermented dairy supplement

vitamin K2 from yeast.notes: Food-based source, includes cofactors and is a suitable natural option.

menadione (K3).notes: Synthetic precursor, not safely used in human supplements due to toxicity concerns.

vitamin K analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

oxidized vitamin K.notes: Degraded by light or heat, loses its activity and becomes ineffective.

calcium citrate.notes: Highly bioavailable form that does not require stomach acid for absorption, making it ideal for those with low stomach acid.

calcium malate.notes: Gentle on digestion and well absorbed. Often combined with malic acid for energy benefits.

calcium bis-glycinate.notes: Chelated form, which means it's bound to amino acids for improved absorption and reduced digestive upset.

calcium hydroxyapatite.notes: Bone-identical structure, derived from bovine bone. Contains other bone-building minerals like phosphorus.

calcium from algae.notes: Plant-based source with trace minerals, derived from marine algae. A popular natural and vegan option.

calcium lactate.notes: Easily dissolved, moderate elemental calcium content. Generally well-tolerated.

calcium gluconate.notes: Low elemental calcium content, but very gentle on the stomach. Often found in chewables.

calcium carbonate.notes: Most common and inexpensive form, but requires stomach acid for absorption, so best taken with food.

calcium phosphate.notes: Poor solubility and low absorption. Often used as a filler rather than a primary calcium source.

dicalcium phosphate.notes: Low solubility, often used as a filler or binder in tablets, not an optimal calcium source.

coral calcium.notes: Often marketed with hype, but quality and absorption are inconsistent. May contain contaminants.

calcium citrate malate.notes: Highly bioavailable and well-absorbed form, often used in fortified juices due to its solubility.

calcium orotate.notes: Bound to orotic acid; claimed to have superior delivery to cells, used in specialty supplements.

calcium ascorbate.notes: Combined with vitamin C, offering a buffered form of calcium that is gentle on the stomach.

calcium oxide.notes: Industrial form, not suitable for human supplementation due to poor bioavailability and potential for irritation.

calcium analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

phosphate salts.notes: Found as monocalcium phosphate, disodium phosphate, potassium phosphate, etc. Essential for bones, energy, and DNA.

magnesium glycinate.notes: Chelated with glycine; highly bioavailable, gentle on the stomach, and less likely to cause laxative effects.

magnesium taurate.notes: Bound to taurine; supports cardiovascular and neurological health, with good absorption.

magnesium citrate.notes: Popular form; good absorption, but may have a mild laxative effect at higher doses.

magnesium malate.notes: Bound to malic acid; supports energy production and muscle function, with good absorption.

magnesium threonate.notes: Unique form that effectively crosses the blood-brain barrier, supporting cognitive function and memory.

magnesium chloride.notes: Versatile form; used orally and topically (e.g., magnesium oil). Good absorption.

magnesium lactate.notes: Gentle on digestion; often used in fortified foods for its good solubility.

magnesium aspartate.notes: Moderate absorption; supports energy metabolism and muscle function.

magnesium orotate.notes: Bound to orotic acid; supports heart health and cellular energy production.

magnesium pidolate.notes: Bound to pyrrolidone carboxylic acid; used in clinical settings for its good bioavailability.

magnesium gluconate.notes: Used in liquid supplements; gentle on the stomach but has a lower elemental magnesium content.

magnesium fumarate.notes: Bound to fumaric acid; supports muscle recovery and energy production.

magnesium succinate.notes: Bound to succinic acid; supports mitochondrial function and cellular energy.

magnesium sulfate.notes: Poor oral absorption; primarily used externally as Epsom salt for baths.

magnesium oxide.notes: High elemental content but poorly absorbed; commonly used as a laxative or antacid due to its low solubility.

magnesium hydroxide.notes: Used as an antacid and laxative ('Milk of Magnesia'); low absorption for systemic magnesium needs.

magnesium carbonate.notes: Used in antacids and supplements; lower solubility and absorption compared to organic forms.

magnesium stearate.notes: Used as a flow agent and lubricant in manufacturing; not a source of supplemental magnesium.

magnesium analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

magnesium bisglycinate.notes: Chelated form with superior absorption compared to oxide. Less GI upset.

iron bisglycinate chelate.notes: Chelated form, gentle on the stomach and highly bioavailable. Minimizes GI side effects common with other iron forms.

ferrous bisglycinate.notes: Well-tolerated chelate, often branded as Ferrochel. Effective for iron repletion with minimal digestive upset.

heme iron polypeptide.notes: Animal-derived, absorbed via the heme pathway, which is highly efficient and not inhibited by dietary factors.

ferritin.notes: Food-based iron storage protein, offering a slow-release, gentle form of iron. Typically derived from legumes.

carbonyl iron.notes: Pure elemental iron in a microparticulate form, offering slow-release and a low toxicity risk.

magnetite iron (Fe3O4).notes: Used in industrial applications or as a coloring agent; not bioavailable for human nutritional needs.

ferrous fumarate.notes: Standard form with high elemental iron content, but can cause significant GI upset like constipation.

ferrous sulfate.notes: Most common and inexpensive form, but frequently causes GI side effects such as constipation and nausea.

ferrous gluconate.notes: Generally gentler on the stomach than ferrous sulfate, but has a lower elemental iron content.

iron polysaccharide.notes: Variable absorption, often used in slow-release formulas to minimize GI upset. Effectiveness can vary greatly.

ferric citrate.notes: Used in phosphate binders for kidney patients; generally has lower absorption for iron supplementation.

ferric pyrophosphate.notes: Used in food fortification due to its stability, but has very low solubility and bioavailability.

ferric ammonium citrate.notes: Used in older formulations, generally has poor bioavailability and can cause GI issues.

ferric oxide.notes: Essentially non-bioavailable for nutritional purposes; primarily used as a red pigment or colorant.

iron analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit and may compete with active iron.

iron fumarate.notes: Better absorbed than iron sulfate with fewer GI side effects.

zinc picolinate.notes: Chelated with picolinic acid; highly bioavailable, well studied, and effectively utilized by the body.

zinc glycinate.notes: Gentle chelated form, bound to glycine for enhanced absorption and minimal GI upset. Well tolerated and effective.

zinc citrate.notes: Well absorbed and a popular alternative to picolinate. Good for general supplementation.

zinc monomethionine (OptiZinc).notes: Patented form; bound to methionine for enhanced uptake and superior retention compared to other zinc forms.

zinc acetate.notes: Used effectively in lozenges to reduce cold duration. Moderate systemic absorption.

zinc gluconate.notes: Common and affordable; moderate absorption. Often found in cold remedies.

zinc orotate.notes: Bound to orotic acid; claimed to enhance cellular delivery, found in specialty formulas.

zinc sulfate.notes: Inexpensive; but may cause nausea or GI upset, particularly on an empty stomach.

zinc carbonate.notes: Poorly absorbed due to low solubility; rarely used as a primary zinc supplement.

zinc oxide.notes: Very low absorption; primarily used topically in sunscreens and barrier creams, not for internal supplementation.

zinc analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit and may interfere with active zinc.

oxidized zinc.notes: Degraded or oxidized zinc; ineffective and provides no biological activity.

zinc bisglycinate.notes: Chelated form with excellent absorption and reduced GI side effects.

inner bark powder.notes: The gold standard form. Derived from the inner bark, which is rich in mucilage, the primary active compound responsible for its soothing, demulcent effects on tissues.

standardized extract (mucilage).notes: A concentrated extract standardized for a high percentage of mucilage. Offers a more potent and consistent dose than simple powder, but is considered a processed form.
aliases: slippery elm bark extract standardized supplement

bark powder (unspecified).notes: When the label just says 'slippery elm bark,' quality can be inconsistent as it may contain a mix of the potent inner bark and the less effective outer bark.

outer bark powder.notes: An inferior, low-quality form derived from the outer bark. It contains significantly less mucilage and is far less effective as a soothing agent. Sometimes used as a cheap filler.
aliases: outer bark of slippery elm supplement

selenomethionine.notes: Organic form, best absorbed and retained by the body, as it's incorporated into proteins similar to dietary selenium.

selenium-methyl L-selenocysteine.notes: Potent synthetic form; direct precursor to methylselenol, a highly active selenium metabolite.

selenized yeast.notes: Food-based source; contains multiple organic selenium species, offering a more complete profile.

selenocysteine.notes: Active form used in selenoproteins, directly contributing to vital enzyme functions. Rare in supplements.

sodium selenite.notes: Common inorganic form; widely used, but absorption and retention are lower than organic forms.

sodium selenate.notes: Inorganic form; less retained by the body and may carry a higher toxicity risk at high doses.

selenium dioxide.notes: Inorganic form, low retention; primarily used in animal feed and some fortification.

selenium-enriched broccoli extract.notes: Food-based source containing naturally occurring organic selenium compounds like Se-methylselenocysteine, offering antioxidant benefits.

selenium-enriched garlic extract.notes: Food-based source containing beneficial selenium compounds, with synergistic effects from garlic constituents.

selenobetaine.notes: Synthetic precursor to methylselenol; often used in experimental cancer research.

methylseleninic acid.notes: Synthetic form; used in cancer research for its direct anti-cancer properties.

selenium glycinate.absorption: Excellent, chelated form for enhanced bioavailability
selenium glycinate.notes: Patented Albion selenium glycinate; known for superior absorption and minimal GI side effects.

selenium analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

oxidized selenium.notes: Degraded or oxidized selenium; ineffective and provides no biological activity.

natural astaxanthin (haematococcus pluvi.absorption: High (fat-soluble; best absorbed with fats or oils)
natural astaxanthin (haematococcus pluvi.notes: Microalgae-derived antioxidant carotenoid used for skin, eye, cognition, and recovery. Clinically preferred form.

synthetic astaxanthin.notes: Petroleum-derived synthetic astaxanthin used in feedstocks and some low-cost supplements. Poorer clinical support.

unspecified astaxanthin.notes: Label discloses astaxanthin but without form or source. No way to confirm bioavailability.

citrus bioflavonoids complex.notes: Natural antioxidant mix from citrus fruits; includes hesperidin, rutin, naringin, and quercetin. Supports Vitamin C activity.

hesperidin.notes: Primary flavanone found in oranges; known for its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.

rutin.notes: Flavonol glycoside; acts as an antioxidant and supports capillary health. Absorption can be limited.

naringin.notes: Bitter flavanone from grapefruit; recognized for its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.

quercetin.notes: Widely studied flavonol; potent antioxidant, antihistamine, and anti-inflammatory agent. Absorption is often poor unless specifically formulated.

creatine monohydrate.notes: The gold standard creatine form with extensive research backing its efficacy for muscle performance and strength.

buffered creatine monohydrate.notes: Marketed as pH-stable to prevent degradation in stomach acid, but limited evidence shows superior absorption over standard monohydrate.

creatine nitrate.notes: Bound to nitrate, which may support nitric oxide production, enhancing blood flow and 'pump' effects during exercise.

creatine hydrochloride.notes: Highly soluble form, which may allow for a lower effective dose compared to monohydrate, but overall efficacy is similar.

creatine ethyl ester.notes: Rapidly degraded to inactive creatinine; generally not recommended due to poor effectiveness.

liposomal saw palmetto.notes: Liposomal delivery enhances cellular uptake and protects active compounds from degradation. Clinically shown to have 2-3x greater bioavailability than standard extracts. Ideal for maximum therapeutic effects.

supercritical CO₂ saw palmetto extract.notes: Solvent-free extraction preserves the full spectrum of fatty acids (lauric, oleic, myristic) and phytosterols. Considered the gold standard for purity and potency. Free from hexane residues.
aliases: supercritical CO2 saw palmetto extract supplement
supercritical fluid extracted saw palmetto supplement

liposterolic extract (85–95% fatty acids.notes: The most clinically researched form. Standardized to contain the active liposterolic compounds shown to support prostate and urinary health. May use ethanol or hexane extraction.

saw palmetto berry powder.notes: Contains the full spectrum of compounds but in much lower concentrations. Requires higher doses for therapeutic effect. Preferred by some for 'whole food' supplementation approaches.

oxidized saw palmetto.notes: Compromised product with destroyed active compounds. May occur due to improper storage (heat, light, oxygen exposure) or expired supplements. Should be avoided.

vanadyl sulfate (VOSO4).notes: Most common vanadium supplement; exhibits insulin-mimetic effects but has low oral bioavailability.

bis(maltolato)oxovanadium (BMOV).notes: Chelated form with superior bioavailability and lower toxicity compared to vanadyl sulfate. More effective.

bis(picolinato)oxovanadium (BPOV).notes: Experimental form with enhanced insulin sensitivity effects, showing promising results in studies.

vanadium analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

myo-inositol.notes: Most abundant and biologically active form; supports cellular signaling, ovarian function, and mood.

d-chiro-inositol.notes: Supports insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism, often used in conjunction with myo-inositol.

inositol hexanicotinate.notes: Bound to niacin; used for cholesterol and vascular support, providing 'no-flush' niacin.

inositol powder (bulk).notes: Highly bioavailable and allows for flexible dosing, commonly used for PCOS and mood support.

inositol analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

copper bisglycinate.notes: Chelated form; gentle on stomach and highly bioavailable. Minimizes potential for GI upset.

copper gluconate.notes: Common form in multivitamins; moderate bioavailability and generally well-tolerated.

copper sulfate.notes: Inexpensive; may cause GI upset or nausea. Less preferred due to potential for irritation.

cupric oxide.notes: Used in some supplements despite very low bioavailability. Primarily used as a pigment.

copper citrate.notes: Bound to citric acid; generally well-tolerated and offers moderate absorption.

copper amino acid chelate.notes: Generic chelated form; absorption depends on the specific amino acid used in the chelate.

copper analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

oxidized copper.notes: Degraded or oxidized copper; ineffective and provides no biological activity.

chromium picolinate.notes: Best studied form; bound to picolinic acid for enhanced uptake. Supports glucose metabolism.

chromium polynicotinate.notes: Niacin-bound form; also supports insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism.

chromium GTF.notes: Glucose tolerance factor; a complex bound to amino acids and niacin, aiming to mimic naturally occurring chromium complexes.

chromium histidinate.notes: Bound to histidine; supports metabolic function and offers good bioavailability.

chromium chloride.notes: Inorganic form; poorly absorbed and generally less effective for supplementation.

chromium analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit.

chromium nicotinate glycinate.notes: Chelated chromium combining nicotinic acid and glycine for enhanced bioavailability and metabolic support.

oxidized chromium.notes: Degraded or oxidized chromium; ineffective and provides no biological activity.

manganese bisglycinate.notes: A chelated form, bound to glycine for superior absorption and minimal GI side effects. It is a highly preferred form for optimal bioavailability.

manganese citrate.notes: An organic form of Manganese, well absorbed and generally gentle on the stomach. It's a common and effective choice in multivitamin formulations.

manganese sulfate.notes: An inorganic form of Manganese with low absorption and a higher likelihood of causing GI upset. Generally less preferred for supplementation.

manganese gluconate.notes: Generally better tolerated than sulfate forms, with moderate bioavailability. A common choice for daily manganese supplementation.

manganese chloride.notes: An inorganic form of Manganese, but typically better absorbed than sulfate. Still generally less bioavailable than organic or chelated forms.

manganese ascorbate.notes: Manganese bound to Vitamin C, which may enhance its absorption and provides synergistic antioxidant benefits.

manganese amino acid chelate.notes: A highly bioavailable generic chelated form of Manganese, offering superior absorption compared to inorganic salts.

food-based manganese.notes: Naturally occurring in whole foods like nuts, grains, and leafy greens. Provides Manganese along with natural cofactors, which may aid in its utilization.

manganese picolinate.notes: Manganese bound to picolinic acid; proponents suggest it improves mineral transport and absorption.

manganese oxide.notes: An inorganic form with very low solubility and absorption. Not an ideal supplemental form for effective delivery.

manganese carbonate.notes: Used in some supplements; generally better absorbed than sulfate forms, but still less than chelates.

manganese aspartate.notes: Chelated with aspartic acid; offers good bioavailability.

manganese orotate.notes: Bound to orotic acid; often used in specialty formulas for its purported delivery advantages to cells.

manganese yeast-bound.notes: Cultured in yeast; considered a natural and food-based source of manganese, potentially offering better bioavailability through its food matrix.

manganese proteinate.notes: Chelated with protein fragments; offers high absorption due to its stable and well-recognized form.

manganese fumarate.notes: Bound to fumaric acid; used in some formulations. Offers moderate absorption.

manganese lactate.notes: Bound to lactic acid; offers decent absorption and is generally well-tolerated.

manganese malate.notes: Bound to malic acid; involved in energy metabolism and offers good bioavailability.

molybdenum glycinate.notes: A chelated form of Molybdenum, bound to glycine. It is gentle on the stomach and highly bioavailable, making it a preferred form for optimal absorption.

sodium molybdate.notes: The standard inorganic form of Molybdenum; widely used in supplements and offers good absorption, although slightly less than chelated forms.

molybdenum amino acid chelate.notes: A generic chelated form of Molybdenum. Its absorption depends on the specific amino acid used in the chelate, but generally offers improved bioavailability over inorganic salts.

molybdenum chloride.notes: Used in some supplements; while better absorbed than some oxides, it is less common and generally less bioavailable than organic forms.

oxidized molybdenum.notes: Molybdenum that has been degraded or oxidized; it is ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality.

molybdenum picolinate.notes: Molybdenum bound to picolinic acid. Offers excellent absorption and is a highly bioavailable form, similar to chromium picolinate.

boron glycinate.notes: A chelated form of Boron, bound to glycine. Offers superior absorption and better gastrointestinal tolerance, making it a highly preferred form.

boron citrate.notes: An organic form of Boron, bound to citric acid. It is well absorbed and generally gentle on the digestive system.

calcium fructoborate.notes: A plant-based boron complex found naturally in fruits and vegetables. Highly bioavailable and stable, considered a premium form.

sodium borate.notes: An inorganic form of Boron; while used, it may cause GI irritation in some individuals and offers moderate absorption.

boron analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar to Boron but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit and may potentially interfere with the body's proper utilization of active Boron.

oxidized boron.notes: Boron that has been degraded or oxidized; it is ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality.

boric acid.notes: A simple inorganic form of boron. While commonly used, organic forms like boron citrate or glycinate are generally preferred for bioavailability and gentleness.

bis(maltolato)oxovanadium(IV).notes: A chelated form of Vanadium with superior bioavailability and lower toxicity compared to simple inorganic forms. Considered a more effective and safer option for supplementation.

vanadyl sulfate.notes: The most studied form of Vanadium in supplements. Exhibits insulin-mimetic effects but has relatively low oral bioavailability, which can limit its effectiveness.

bis(picolinato)oxovanadium (BPOV).notes: An experimental form of Vanadium showing enhanced insulin sensitivity effects in preliminary studies. Offers good bioavailability and is an area of ongoing research.

sodium vanadate.notes: A basic inorganic form of Vanadium; exhibits very low bioavailability when taken orally, making it less effective for supplementation.

vanadium analogs (non-functional).notes: Structurally similar to Vanadium but biologically inactive; offers no nutritional benefit and may potentially interfere with the body's proper utilization of active Vanadium.

oxidized vanadium.notes: Vanadium that has been degraded or oxidized; it is ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality.

potassium citrate.notes: A highly bioavailable organic salt of Potassium; it is alkalizing and kidney-friendly, commonly used for urinary and bone health, and to support blood pressure.

potassium gluconate.notes: A gentle organic form of Potassium; it is well absorbed and a common ingredient in over-the-counter supplements for electrolyte balance.

potassium chloride.notes: A standard inorganic form of Potassium; widely used as a salt substitute but can cause GI upset in some individuals due to its chloride content.

potassium bicarbonate.notes: An alkalizing agent; it can help neutralize stomach acid but may cause bloating or GI irritation in sensitive individuals. Often used for pH balance.

potassium aspartate.notes: Potassium bound to the amino acid aspartate. Offers moderate absorption.

potassium phosphate.notes: Used in electrolyte replacement formulas; provides both Potassium and Phosphorus. Absorption can be variable depending on the specific phosphate form.

oxidized potassium.notes: Potassium that has been degraded or oxidized; it is ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality.

potassium orotate.notes: Potassium bound to orotic acid. Proponents claim it enhances cellular delivery, making it a specialty form for targeted effects.

triglyceride form.notes: The natural form of Omega-3s found in fish oil. It is best absorbed and retained by the body, mimicking how fatty acids are consumed in food.

epa (eicosapentaenoic acid).absorption: excellent (when in triglyceride or phospholipid form, >90%)
epa (eicosapentaenoic acid).notes: EPA is a main omega-3 fatty acid found in fish and marine oils, known for its cardiovascular, anti-inflammatory, and mood benefits.

dha (docosahexaenoic acid).absorption: excellent (when in triglyceride or phospholipid form, >90%)
dha (docosahexaenoic acid).notes: DHA is a major structural component in brain, eye, and nerve tissue—essential for neurodevelopment, visual health, and cell function.

unspecified omega-3.notes: Used when label gives no meaningful info except 'omega-3.' Likely low quality/bioavailability.

phospholipid form (krill).notes: Omega-3s bound to phospholipids, typically found in krill oil. This form is thought to be highly bioavailable due to its structural similarity to cell membranes, supporting brain and cellular health.

re-esterified triglyceride.notes: A processed form of Omega-3s where ethyl esters are converted back into a triglyceride structure. Offers concentrated EPA/DHA with very good absorption.

algae oil (vegan).notes: A plant-based source of Omega-3s, specifically DHA (and sometimes EPA). It is an excellent vegan alternative to fish oil, derived from marine algae.

ethyl ester.notes: A concentrated form of Omega-3s used in many supplements, including pharmaceutical-grade fish oils. It requires fat for optimal absorption and some individuals find it less bioavailable than triglyceride forms.

fish oil (unrefined).notes: Less processed fish oil; may have lower purity and variable EPA/DHA content compared to refined concentrates. Can also have a stronger fishy taste.

micronized omega-3.notes: Processed to have a smaller particle size, which improves its solubility and uptake, leading to higher bioavailability and reduced fishy burps.

liposomal omega-3.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for significantly enhanced delivery and stability. Protects the Omega-3s from oxidation and degradation, ensuring maximum bioavailability.

oxidized omega-3.notes: Omega-3s that have been degraded by exposure to light, heat, or oxygen. Ineffective and potentially harmful (e.g., rancid). Indicates poor product quality.

flaxseed oil.notes: A plant-based source of ALA (alpha-linolenic acid), which is an Omega-3 fatty acid. It has limited conversion to EPA and DHA in the human body.

cod liver oil.notes: A natural source of Omega-3s (EPA and DHA), along with naturally occurring Vitamin A and D. Offers a holistic nutrient profile.

ubiquinol.notes: The reduced, active form of CoQ10; readily utilized by the body without conversion. Ideal for individuals over 40 or those with impaired CoQ10 conversion ability.

micellized CoQ10.notes: A water-soluble micelle form of CoQ10; significantly enhances uptake, particularly beneficial for individuals with fat malabsorption or digestive issues.

liposomal CoQ10.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes; protects CoQ10 against degradation and significantly improves its delivery and bioavailability to cells.

ubiquinone with piperine.notes: Ubiquinone enhanced with black pepper extract (piperine) to inhibit its metabolism and improve overall absorption, leading to higher circulating levels.

ubiquinone (standard).notes: The oxidized form of CoQ10. It requires conversion to ubiquinol in the body, which can be inefficient, especially in older individuals or those with certain health conditions.

ubiquinone powder.notes: A dry crystalline form of Ubiquinone with very low solubility and consequently poor absorption. Not an ideal form for effective supplementation.

crystal-free CoQ10.notes: A pre-dissolved formulation of CoQ10 that prevents crystal reformation, significantly improving its solubility and overall uptake in the body.

oxidized CoQ10.notes: CoQ10 that has been degraded by exposure to light, heat, or oxidation; it becomes ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability.

disodium PQQ.notes: A stable, water-soluble form of PQQ that is most studied for its role in mitochondrial biogenesis (new mitochondrial growth) and neurological support. Highly bioavailable.

PQQ with CoQ10.notes: A synergistic combination of PQQ and CoQ10, supporting both the quantity (PQQ) and efficiency (CoQ10) of mitochondria for enhanced cellular energy and overall vitality.

PQQ acid.notes: The free acid form of PQQ; it is generally less stable and less bioavailable than the disodium salt, making it a less preferred option for supplementation.

microactive PQQ.notes: A sustained-release formulation of PQQ with enhanced uptake and a longer residence time in the body, ensuring more consistent delivery of its benefits.

liposomal PQQ.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for enhanced delivery and stability. Protects PQQ from degradation and improves its cellular uptake, maximizing effectiveness.

oxidized PQQ.notes: PQQ that has been degraded or oxidized; it is ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality.

liposomal glutathione.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes; effectively bypasses digestive breakdown and significantly enhances cellular delivery and absorption, making it highly bioavailable and effective as a systemic antioxidant.

s-acetyl glutathione.notes: A stable, acetylated form of Glutathione; it is absorbed intact and then converted intracellularly, offering superior bioavailability compared to standard reduced glutathione.

reduced glutathione with vitamin C.notes: Formulated with Vitamin C, which helps protect Glutathione (GSH) from oxidation and supports its recycling in the body, potentially enhancing its effectiveness over GSH alone.
aliases: reduced glutathione with vitamin c supplement

standard glutathione.notes: Refers to standard Reduced Glutathione (GSH). It is largely broken down in the gut by enzymes before absorption, leading to very limited systemic uptake and effectiveness.

oxidized glutathione.notes: The inactive disulfide form (GSSG) of Glutathione; it is not suitable for supplementation as it does not directly contribute to the body's active GSH pool and needs to be reduced.

NAC (precursor).notes: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is a highly effective precursor that boosts the body's endogenous production of glutathione. It is a more efficient way to increase intracellular GSH levels than oral GSH itself.

streptococcus salivarius k12.notes: A specific probiotic strain clinically studied for oral and upper respiratory tract health. Produces antimicrobial peptides (bacteriocins) called BLIS that help maintain healthy oral microflora.

streptococcus salivarius m18.notes: A specialized probiotic strain researched for dental health benefits. Produces specific bacteriocins that target cavity-causing bacteria and supports healthy gum tissue.

enteric coated.notes: Probiotics in delayed-release capsules that protect the delicate strains from harsh stomach acid, ensuring optimal delivery and survival to the intestines for colonization and benefit.

spore-based.notes: Probiotics (typically Bacillus strains) that form natural spores. These spores are highly resistant to heat, acid, and bile, ensuring excellent survival through the digestive tract and effective colonization.

liposomal probiotics.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for improved delivery and shelf stability. This advanced technology helps protect the live cultures from harsh conditions and enhances their targeted release.

liquid probiotics.notes: Probiotic strains suspended in a liquid medium. Often sold in vials or drops, particularly for infants. Offers rapid absorption but can have variable shelf stability.

freeze-dried with prebiotics.notes: A symbiotic format where freeze-dried probiotic strains are combined with prebiotics (fiber that feeds beneficial bacteria). Prebiotics nourish the strains during transit and in the gut, improving viability.

refrigerated live.notes: Probiotics that require cold-chain storage to maintain viability. While generally highly effective, their survival depends heavily on proper handling and storage from manufacturing to consumption.

probiotic gummies/chewables.notes: A common delivery format for consumer convenience. However, the strains often have lower CFU counts and are less stable due to moisture and heat exposure during manufacturing and storage.

non-enteric coated capsules.notes: Standard probiotic capsules without acid protection. Most sensitive strains may die in stomach acid, resulting in low delivery of live organisms to the intestines and reduced effectiveness.

oxidized probiotics.notes: Probiotic cultures that have been degraded by exposure to heat, moisture, or oxygen. This leads to a significant loss of viability, making them ineffective and providing no biological activity.

lactobacillus acidophilus.notes: A well-known and widely studied probiotic strain that supports gut flora balance, vitamin synthesis, and immune modulation. Often part of multi-strain blends.

lactobacillus rhamnosus gg.notes: A highly clinically validated probiotic strain, known for its excellent survival through gastric acid and bile, and its benefits for digestive and immune health. Often branded as LGG.

lactobacillus rhamnosus.notes: A robust probiotic strain with good acid and bile tolerance. Different from LGG strain but still provides digestive and immune benefits.

lactobacillus plantarum.notes: A robust and resilient strain naturally found in fermented foods. It adheres well to the gut lining and has benefits for digestive comfort and immune function.

lactobacillus reuteri.notes: A strain known for its ability to produce antimicrobial substances (reuterin) and its benefits for infant colic, oral health, and gut barrier integrity. Often branded as DSM 17938 or Protectis.

lactobacillus gasseri.notes: A probiotic strain that may help with weight management and metabolic health in addition to digestive benefits.

lactobacillus helveticus.notes: A probiotic strain commonly used in cheese production, may help with blood pressure regulation and stress reduction.

lactobacillus casei.notes: A versatile probiotic strain that supports digestive health and immune function. Often confused with L. paracasei due to genetic similarity.

bifidobacterium longum.notes: A key probiotic strain that colonizes the colon, supporting immune and digestive health. Often included in comprehensive probiotic formulations.

bifidobacterium longum subsp. infantis.notes: Specifically adapted to infant gut environment, helps with digestion of breast milk oligosaccharides and supports infant immune development.

bifidobacterium lactis.notes: A well-researched strain supporting digestive comfort, immune health, and reducing the incidence of antibiotic-associated diarrhea. Often branded as Bifidobacterium animalis subsp. lactis.

bifidobacterium bifidum.notes: A beneficial probiotic strain naturally present in the human gut microbiome, supporting digestive health and immune function. Known for its ability to help maintain healthy gut barrier function.

saccharomyces boulardii.notes: A unique yeast-based probiotic, highly resistant to antibiotics and stomach acid. Beneficial for travelers' diarrhea and antibiotic-associated diarrhea. Often branded as Florastor.

multi-strain blend (10+ strains).notes: A broad-spectrum formula containing 10 or more different probiotic strains, aiming for synergistic effects across various regions of the gut microbiome. Individual strain CFUs are important for efficacy.

bacillus coagulans.notes: A spore-forming probiotic with characteristics of both Bacillus and Lactobacillus. Excellent acid and bile tolerance due to spore formation.

bacillus subtilis.notes: A spore-forming probiotic with excellent environmental resistance. Supports gut health and may help with antibiotic-associated disruption.

bacillus clausii.notes: A spore-forming probiotic with natural antibiotic resistance, making it suitable for use during antibiotic therapy.

bacillus indicus.notes: A spore-forming probiotic strain that may help with gut barrier function and inflammation reduction.

yogurt cultures.notes: Probiotic strains commonly used as starter cultures for yogurt and cheese. While they provide some benefits (e.g., lactose digestion), their survival in the human gut is limited compared to dedicated probiotic strains.

inulin.notes: A fructo-oligosaccharide polymer (DP 3-60) that selectively feeds beneficial bacteria, particularly Bifidobacterium. Degree of polymerization affects fermentation location and rate.

fructooligosaccharides (FOS).notes: Short-chain fructo-oligosaccharides (DP 2-20) that rapidly ferment in the proximal colon, preferentially feeding Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus.

galactooligosaccharides (GOS).notes: Oligosaccharides derived from lactose that selectively promote beneficial bacteria growth, particularly Bifidobacterium. Well-tolerated and effective.

xylooligosaccharides (XOS).notes: Oligosaccharides derived from xylan that selectively feed beneficial bacteria. Effective at lower doses compared to other prebiotics.

human milk oligosaccharides (HMO).notes: Complex oligosaccharides naturally found in breast milk. Highly specific for beneficial bacteria and immune modulation.

beta-glucan.notes: Soluble fiber from oats, barley, and mushrooms that supports beneficial bacteria and provides immune benefits.

resistant starch.notes: Starch that resists digestion and ferments in the colon, producing beneficial short-chain fatty acids, particularly butyrate.

acacia fiber.notes: Soluble fiber from acacia trees that gently supports beneficial bacteria with minimal digestive side effects.

pectin.notes: Soluble fiber from fruits that supports beneficial bacteria and may help with cholesterol management.

psyllium husk.notes: Mostly insoluble fiber that provides bulk and some prebiotic benefits, though less selective than other prebiotics.

mixed prebiotic blend.notes: Combination of multiple prebiotics (typically FOS, GOS, and inulin) that provides comprehensive support for diverse beneficial bacteria populations.

alpha-GPC.notes: A highly bioavailable form of Choline that effectively crosses the blood-brain barrier. It boosts acetylcholine levels, supporting cognitive function, memory, and athletic performance.

CDP-choline (citicoline).notes: A potent cognitive enhancer. It supports the synthesis of brain phospholipids and acetylcholine, providing neuroprotection and improving focus, memory, and overall brain function. Often branded as Cognizin.

phosphatidylcholine.notes: A lipid-soluble form of Choline, a major component of cell membranes. Supports liver health, fat metabolism, and is a precursor to acetylcholine. Commonly found in lecithin extracts.

choline bitartrate.notes: A basic salt form of Choline; it is cost-effective but has limited brain uptake compared to more advanced forms like Alpha-GPC or Citicoline.

choline citrate.notes: A liquid-friendly form of Choline. It offers better solubility but is generally less effective for direct brain benefits compared to specialized choline sources.

choline chloride.notes: A highly soluble form of Choline, but primarily used in veterinary and industrial applications due to its cost-effectiveness and high elemental choline content. Less common in human supplements.

liposomal choline.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for enhanced delivery and stability. Improves brain uptake and overall bioavailability by protecting Choline from degradation in the digestive system.

oxidized choline.notes: Choline that has been degraded or oxidized; it is ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality.

sunflower phosphatidylserine.notes: A non-GMO and allergen-free source of Phosphatidylserine, derived from sunflower. Supports cognitive function (memory, focus) and helps regulate the body's stress response (cortisol). Often branded as Sharp-PS.

soy-derived phosphatidylserine.notes: A well-studied form of Phosphatidylserine derived from soy lecithin. Supports cognition and cortisol regulation, but consider potential soy allergens or GMO concerns.

bovine phosphatidylserine.notes: An animal-derived form of Phosphatidylserine (from bovine brain). While effective, it carries regulatory concerns in some regions due to potential prion risk and is less commonly used now.

liposomal phosphatidylserine.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for enhanced delivery and stability. Improves its cellular uptake and bioavailability, maximizing its benefits for cognitive and stress support.

Actiserine (enhanced PS blend).notes: A clinically validated blend (often with catechins and arabinose) designed to significantly enhance the absorption and effectiveness of Phosphatidylserine.

oxidized phosphatidylserine.notes: Phosphatidylserine that has been degraded or oxidized; it becomes ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality.

taurine (generic).notes: A fundamental amino acid, highly absorbed via active transport. Supports cardiovascular, neurological, and metabolic health. Synthetic form is chemically identical to natural form.

magnesium taurate.notes: A chelated form combining taurine with magnesium. This synergistic combination enhances the bioavailability of both nutrients, making it highly effective for cardiovascular and nervous system support.

taurine with coq10.notes: A popular combination for cardiovascular support. Taurine works with CoQ10 to protect heart cells, though this is a blend and not a unique chemical form of taurine itself.

taurine liquid/drops.notes: A highly bioavailable form due to its liquid state, offering rapid absorption and flexible dosing. No difference in bioavailability from powder, but may be faster acting.

liposomal taurine.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for potential enhanced cellular delivery, though taurine is already highly bioavailable. This form may be best for targeting specific cells.

taurine from food.notes: Taurine from dietary sources, primarily meat and seafood. It is highly bioavailable, though the exact amount is dependent on the food matrix.

oxidized taurine.notes: Taurine that has been degraded. It's ineffective and indicates a low-quality or expired product. [FLAG: Low Efficacy]

liposomal l-carnitine.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for superior bioavailability, stability, and cellular uptake. This form is designed to maximize the benefits of L-Carnitine, especially for targeted delivery.

acetyl-l-carnitine (alcar).notes: An ester form that effectively crosses the blood-brain barrier. It supports cognitive function, memory, and mitochondrial health, making it the preferred choice for brain support.

l-carnitine tartrate (lclt).notes: A highly bioavailable salt form commonly used in sports supplements. It is clinically studied to support energy metabolism, muscle recovery, and reduce exercise-induced muscle damage.

propionyl-l-carnitine (plc).notes: A form of L-Carnitine that supports nitric oxide production and peripheral circulation. It is often used for cardiovascular health and may be beneficial for exercise performance.

l-carnitine fumarate.notes: A stable form of L-Carnitine bound to fumaric acid, which is an intermediate in the Krebs cycle. It is used to support cellular energy production and cardiovascular health.

l-carnitine base (free form).notes: The unbound, free form of L-Carnitine. While effective, it generally has lower stability and uptake compared to its salt or ester forms due to poor intestinal absorption.

l-carnitine from food.notes: Naturally occurring L-Carnitine in food, primarily red meat and dairy. Absorption from food is significantly lower than from supplements, but it is a natural source.

d-carnitine.notes: The inactive stereoisomer of L-Carnitine. It is biologically inert and can actually inhibit the body's use of L-Carnitine, indicating a low-quality product. [FLAG: Inactive Form]

oxidized l-carnitine.notes: L-Carnitine that has been degraded or oxidized from improper storage or age. It is ineffective and provides no biological activity. [FLAG: Low Efficacy]

betaine anhydrous.notes: The primary methyl donor form of Betaine. Highly bioavailable and effective for homocysteine reduction, liver function, and athletic performance.

betaine from food.notes: TMG derived directly from whole food sources, primarily beets, spinach, and quinoa. Bioavailability is excellent, providing a natural source of this methyl donor.

liposomal tmg.notes: TMG encapsulated in liposomes for enhanced delivery and stability, potentially increasing cellular uptake and efficacy. May be preferred for targeted delivery.

betaine hydrochloride.notes: A form used as a stomach acid supplement to aid digestion. It is NOT the same as Betaine Anhydrous and does not serve a methylation or liver support role in the same way.

tmg in blend.notes: A generic mention of TMG within a proprietary blend without specifying the exact form (anhydrous, HCl, etc.). The efficacy is uncertain due to lack of transparency and unknown dosage. [FLAG: Proprietary Blend]

oxidized tmg.notes: Degraded or oxidized Betaine that is ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality. [FLAG: Low Efficacy]

l-glutamine powder.notes: The most common and widely used form of L-Glutamine. Highly soluble and effective for muscle recovery, immune support, and gut health.

l-alanyl-l-glutamine.notes: A dipeptide form of Glutamine that is more stable in liquid solutions and during digestion. It may offer enhanced absorption and hydration benefits over free-form L-Glutamine.

n-acetyl-l-glutamine.notes: An acetylated form of Glutamine. While it may have enhanced stability, it must be deacetylated in the body, which can make it less efficient than standard L-Glutamine.

l-glutamine from food.notes: Glutamine from food sources such as beef, chicken, fish, dairy, and some vegetables. Bioavailability is good, but quantity can vary. It also contains the 3-point bonus for being a natural form.

l-arginine akG.notes: Arginine bound to Alpha-Ketoglutarate. This salt form is designed for enhanced stability and absorption, making it a popular choice for nitric oxide support and pumps.

l-arginine hcl.notes: Arginine bound to hydrochloric acid. A stable and well-absorbed salt form that supports nitric oxide production and circulation.

l-arginine base.notes: The free-form, un-bound version of Arginine. While effective, it is less stable and generally has a lower bioavailability compared to its salt forms.

arginine aspartate.notes: A salt of arginine and aspartic acid. It is well-absorbed and may have additional benefits from the aspartic acid component.

l-lysine hcl.notes: The most common and highly bioavailable form of this essential amino acid. It is crucial for protein synthesis, collagen formation, and immune function.

l-lysine base.notes: The free-form version of Lysine. While highly effective, it may be slightly less stable and can be more prone to degradation than the HCl salt form.

lysine from food.notes: An essential amino acid from food sources like meat, cheese, and legumes. Provides the natural form with excellent bioavailability and the 3-point natural bonus.

n-acetyl l-tyrosine.notes: An acetylated form of Tyrosine with enhanced water solubility and stability. It is often preferred for cognitive function as it can cross the blood-brain barrier more efficiently than the base form.

l-tyrosine powder.notes: The standard free-form amino acid. It is a precursor to neurotransmitters like dopamine and adrenaline, but absorption can be less efficient than NALT.

d-tyrosine.notes: The inactive stereoisomer of L-Tyrosine. It does not provide the same biological effects and may interfere with L-Tyrosine's absorption. [FLAG: Inactive Form]

n-acetyl cysteine (nac).notes: A highly stable and bioavailable precursor to L-Cysteine and the master antioxidant, Glutathione. It is the most common and effective supplemental form.

l-cysteine base.notes: The free-form amino acid. It is less stable and less bioavailable than NAC, but still provides a source of cysteine.

l-proline powder.notes: The standard free-form amino acid. It is a key component of collagen and supports joint, skin, and connective tissue health.

hydroxyproline.notes: A modified amino acid that is a major component of collagen. It is often found in collagen peptides and is a good marker for collagen content.

proline from collagen.notes: Proline naturally found in hydrolyzed collagen peptides. Highly bioavailable as it is part of the whole food matrix. Includes the 3-point natural bonus.

l-glycine powder.notes: A simple but crucial amino acid. It is a precursor to glutathione, supports sleep, and is a key component of collagen. Highly bioavailable and well-tolerated.

glycine from gelatin.notes: Glycine from a natural, food-based source like gelatin or hydrolyzed collagen. Highly bioavailable and offers the 3-point natural bonus.

bcaa 2:1:1.notes: The most common and clinically studied ratio of Leucine, Isoleucine, and Valine. It is highly effective for muscle protein synthesis and recovery.

bcaa 4:1:1.notes: A BCAA ratio with a higher concentration of Leucine to maximize muscle protein synthesis, often preferred for bodybuilders and athletes.

instantized bcaas.notes: BCAAs that have been treated for enhanced solubility in water, making them easier to mix and absorb quickly. Does not alter bioavailability but improves user experience.

bcaa peptides.notes: BCAAs linked into short peptide chains. This form may be absorbed even faster than free-form BCAAs, potentially improving muscle delivery.

l-tryptophan powder.notes: An essential amino acid and a precursor to serotonin and melatonin. Commonly used to support mood and sleep. Highly bioavailable.

5-htp.notes: The direct precursor to serotonin. It bypasses the rate-limiting step of tryptophan conversion, making it a more direct and potent source for serotonin production. It is not an amino acid but is often grouped with them.

tryptophan from food.notes: Tryptophan from protein-rich foods like turkey and eggs. Bioavailability is good, but uptake to the brain is limited by competition with other amino acids.

gaba powder.notes: A non-protein amino acid and the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the CNS. Used for relaxation and sleep. While highly absorbed in the gut, its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier is limited.

pharma-gaba.notes: A patented, naturally fermented form of GABA. Clinically shown to be highly effective and bioavailable for relaxation and stress reduction. Includes the 3-point natural bonus.

liposomal gaba.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes to enhance its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier, potentially increasing its calming and neurological effects.

carnosyn beta-alanine.notes: A patented, clinically studied form of Beta-Alanine. It is the gold standard for raising muscle carnosine levels and is proven to enhance athletic performance and endurance.

beta-alanine powder.notes: The standard free-form amino acid. It is highly effective for increasing muscle carnosine, but may not be as pure or clinically validated as branded forms.

stabilized sulforaphane.notes: A direct, stable form of Sulforaphane; it bypasses the need for enzymatic conversion, ensuring high bioavailability and consistent delivery of its benefits.

broccoli sprout extract.notes: A natural source containing glucoraphanin and active myrosinase enzyme. Supports effective conversion to sulforaphane upon ingestion, offering significant health benefits.

glucoraphanin.notes: A precursor to Sulforaphane. It requires enzymatic conversion via myrosinase or gut microbiota to become active, which can limit its overall effectiveness if myrosinase is insufficient.

glucoraphanin + myrosinase.notes: An optimized formulation that combines glucoraphanin with active myrosinase enzyme. This ensures efficient conversion to sulforaphane upon ingestion, mimicking natural enzymatic hydrolysis for superior bioavailability.

liposomal sulforaphane.notes: Encapsulated in liposomes for enhanced delivery and stability. Protects Sulforaphane from degradation and significantly improves its cellular uptake and bioavailability.

oxidized sulforaphane.notes: Sulforaphane that has been degraded by exposure to heat, light, or pH fluctuations; it becomes ineffective and provides no biological activity. Indicates compromised product stability and quality.

fresh spirulina paste.notes: Unprocessed, enzymatically active; highest nutrient integrity

organic spirulina.notes: Certified organic; free of contaminants and additives

spirulina powder.notes: Highly digestible; no cellulose wall; rich in protein and phycocyanin

spirulina tablets.notes: Compressed form; slower digestion than powder

oxidized spirulina.notes: Degraded by heat or oxidation; ineffective [FLAG: Review for removal due to low efficacy]

fermented chlorella.notes: Pre-digested via enzymatic fermentation; enhanced nutrient release

broken cell wall chlorella.notes: Mechanically disrupted wall; improves digestibility and detox potential

chlorella powder.notes: Whole-cell form; limited absorption due to intact cellulose wall

chlorella tablets.notes: Compressed form; absorption depends on wall integrity and binders

oxidized chlorella.notes: Degraded by heat or oxidation; ineffective [FLAG: Review for removal due to low efficacy]

oligosaccharide HA.notes: Ultra-low molecular weight; penetrates intestinal epithelium and skin layers

liposomal HA.notes: Encapsulated for enhanced delivery and skin penetration

acetylated HA.notes: Modified for improved stability and antioxidant activity

low molecular weight HA.notes: Absorbed in cecum; supports systemic hydration and skin elasticity
aliases: low molecular weight hyaluronic acid supplement

high molecular weight HA.notes: Large molecules; systemic distribution but limited absorption
aliases: high molecular weight hyaluronic acid supplement

oxidized HA.notes: Degraded by heat or light; ineffective [FLAG: Review for removal due to low efficacy]

R-alpha-lipoic acid.notes: Biologically active enantiomer; superior mitochondrial uptake and antioxidant potency

liposomal alpha-lipoic acid.notes: Encapsulated for enhanced stability, solubility, and cellular delivery

ALA with biotin.notes: Biotin supports glucose metabolism and synergizes with ALA

granulated alpha-lipoic acid.notes: Polymer-coated granules resist stomach acid degradation

racemic alpha-lipoic acid.notes: 50:50 mix of R and S enantiomers; lower efficacy and stability

oxidized alpha-lipoic acid.notes: Degraded by heat, light, or pH; ineffective [FLAG: Review for removal due to low efficacy]

liposomal MSM.notes: Encapsulated for enhanced delivery and cellular uptake

MSM with vitamin C.notes: Vitamin C enhances MSM uptake and synergizes antioxidant effects

MSM (methylsulfonylmethane).notes: Highly bioavailable sulfur donor; supports joints, detox, and antioxidant synthesis

oxidized MSM.notes: Degraded or polymerized MSM; ineffective [FLAG: Review for removal due to low efficacy]

KSM-66 ashwagandha.notes: Full-spectrum root extract; high withanolide content; clinically validated for stress, testosterone, and cognition

liposomal ashwagandha.notes: Encapsulated for enhanced delivery and stability

sensoril ashwagandha.notes: Patented leaf + root extract; higher withanolide concentration; focused on stress and cortisol reduction

ashwagandha with piperine.notes: Black pepper extract boosts absorption via piperine

standard ashwagandha extract.notes: Generic extract; variable potency and withanolide content

ashwagandha powder.notes: Whole root powder; traditional use; low standardization

oxidized ashwagandha.notes: Degraded by heat or light; ineffective [FLAG: Review for removal due to low efficacy]

rhodiola rosea extract (3% rosavins).notes: Standardized extract; adaptogenic effects on stress, fatigue, and cognition

liposomal rhodiola.notes: Encapsulated for enhanced delivery and stability
